{{Refimprove|date=November 2008}} {{otherusesof}} {{Infobox UK place |static_image_name= Butter Cross, Whittlesey - geograph.org.uk - 1554357.jpg |static_image_caption= Market square |country = England |official_name= Whittlesey (Whittlesea) |os_grid_reference= TL271967 |coordinates = {{coord|52.558|-0.130|display=inline,title}} | population = 16,058 | population_ref = (2011 Census)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadKeyFigures.do?a=7&b=11130597&c=Whittlesey&d=16&e=62&g=6405697&i=1001x1003x1032x1004&m=0&r=1&s=1448576446469&enc=1 |title=2011 Census Profile - Whittlesey Parish eb site}}</ref> |civil_parish= Whittlesey |shire_district= [[Fenland District|Fenland]] |shire_county = [[Cambridgeshire]] |region= East of England |constituency_westminster= |post_town= PETERBOROUGH |postcode_district = PE7 |postcode_area= PE |dial_code= 01733 }} '''Whittlesey''' is a [[market town]] {{convert|6|mi|km|0}} east of [[Peterborough]] in the [[Fenland District|Fenland]] district of [[Cambridgeshire]], England. Including the neighbouring villages of [[Coates, Cambridgeshire|Coates]], [[Eastrea]], [[Pondersbridge]] and Turves, it had a population of 16,058 at the 2011 Census.
==Location== Whittlesey is between [[Peterborough]], {{convert|6|mi|km|0}} to the west, and [[March, Cambridgeshire|March]], {{convert|11|mi|km|0}} to the east, and is bordered to the north by the [[River Nene]] and to the south by Whittlesey Dyke. Historically it was connected to Peterborough and March by the [[Roman roads|Roman road]] [[Fen Causeway]] constructed in the first century AD, a route approximately followed by the modern [[A605 road|A605]].
[[Whittlesea railway station]], using the town name's older spelling, is on the [[Ely to Peterborough Line]], with direct trains to [[Cambridge]], [[Birmingham]], [[Liverpool]], [[Leicester]], [[Stansted Airport]], [[Ely, Cambridgeshire|Ely]], [[Ipswich]] and Peterborough.
==History and architecture==
[[File:St. Marys spire.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The spire of St Mary's church viewed from the west]] Whittlesey appears in the ''Cartularium Saxonicum'' (973 A.D.) as Witlesig, in the [[Domesday Book]] as Witesie, and in the ''Inquisitio Eliensis''<ref>''Inquisition Eliensis'', abbreviated "IE": a "satellite" section of the Domesday Book, listing the lands belonging to the abbey of Ely {{cite web |url=http://www.domesdaybook.net/helpfiles/hs690.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526134400/http://www.domesdaybook.net/helpfiles/hs690.htm |archivedate=26 May 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> (1086 A.D.) as Wittleseia. The meaning is "Wit(t)el's island", deriving from either Witil, "the name of a moneyer", or a diminutive of Witta, a personal name; + "eg", meaning "'island', also used of a piece of firm land in a fen."<ref>{{cite book |first=Eilert |last=Ekwall |title=The Concise Oxford Dictionary of English Place-Names |year=1960 |edition=4th |publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref>
Before the draining of the fens, Whittlesey was an island of dry ground surrounded by the marshy fens. Excavations of nearby [[Flag Fen]] indicate thriving local settlements as far back as 1000 BC. At Must Farm quarry, [[Must Farm Bronze Age settlement|a Bronze Age settlement]] is described as "Britain's [[Pompeii]]" due to its relatively good condition.<ref name="BBC-35280290">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cambridgeshire-35280290 |title=Bronze Age houses uncovered in Cambridgeshire are Britain's 'Pompeii' |date=12 January 2016 |work=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=12 January 2016}}</ref> In 2016 it was being excavated by the [[University of Cambridge]]'s Cambridge Archaeological Unit.<ref name="MF">{{cite web |url=http://www.mustfarm.com/ |title=Must Farm |accessdate=12 January 2016}}</ref> At [[Must Farm]] at least five homes of 3,000 years in age have been found, along with Britain's most complete prehistoric wooden wheel, dating back to the late Bronze Age.
In more recent times Whittlesey was linked to [[Peterborough]] in the west and [[March, Cambridgeshire|March]] in the east by the [[Roman Britain|Roman]] [[Fen Causeway]], probably built in the 1st century AD. Roman artefacts have been recovered at nearby Eldernell,{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} and a Roman skeleton was discovered in the nearby village of [[Eastrea]] during construction of its village hall in 2010.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cambstimes.co.uk/home/could_this_be_whittlesey_s_earliest_known_resident_1_596148 |title=Could this be Whittlesey's earliest known resident? |work=[[Archant|Cambs Times]] |date=20 August 2010 |first=Andrew |last=Papworth}}</ref>
The town's two parishes of St Mary's and St Andrew's were controlled by the abbeys in [[Thorney Abbey|Thorney]] and Ely respectively until the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries]] (c. 1540). The two parishes were combined for administrative purposes by the Whittlesey Improvement Act of 1849. Despite the proximity of [[Peterborough]], Whittlesey is in the [[Diocese of Ely]].
Until it was drained in 1851, nearby [[Whittlesey Mere]] was a substantial lake surrounded by marsh. According to the traveller [[Celia Fiennes]], who saw it in 1697, the mere was "3 mile broad and six mile long. In the midst is a little island where a great store of Wildfowle breed.... The ground is all wett and marshy but there are severall little Channells runs into it which by boats people go up to this place; when you enter the mouth of the Mer it looks formidable and its often very dangerous by reason of sudden winds that will rise like Hurricanes...."<ref>''The Journeys of Celia Fiennes''. Edited and introduced by Christopher Morris (London: The [[Cresset Press]], 1949), p. 67.</ref> The town is still accessible by water, connected to the river Nene by King's Dyke, which forms part of the Nene/Ouse Navigation link. Moorings can be found at Ashline Lock, alongside the Manor Leisure Centre's cricket and football pitches.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}>
Whittlesey was noted for its [[brickyard]]s, around which the former hamlet of King's Dyke was based for much of the 20th century, although only one now remains, following the closure of the Saxon brickworks in 2011.<ref>London Brick [http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/features/news-features/building-a-history-of-the-glory-days-of-london-brick-1-3656693].</ref>
The local clay soil was also used to make [[Cob (material)|cob]] boundary walls during a period in which there was a tax on bricks. Some examples of these roofed walls still stand today and are unique in Fenland.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
Whittlesey was infamous for its number of [[pub|public houses]]; folklore dictates that, at one time there were 52 of them – one for each week of the year.<ref name=Memories>''Millennium Memories of Whittlesey'' – a series of books on Whittlesey history. Published on behalf of the Whittlesey Museum.</ref> In 1797, a local farmer noted in his diary "they like drinking better than fighting in Whittlesea."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=21904&strquery=whittlesey |title=North Witchford Hundred - Whittlesey |work=A History of the County of Cambridge and the Isle of Ely: Volume 4: City of Ely; Ely, N. and S. Witchford and Wisbech Hundreds |year=2002 |pages=123–135 |editor=R B Pugh}}</ref>
In other history, Whittlesey was an important trade route in the late Bronze Age (about 1100–800 BC), where civilisations traded with many places, including the Balkans. Such evidence is clear at the important archaeological site of Must Farm, where log boats, roundhouses, bowls with food in them, and the most complete wooden wheel were housed.
===Churches=== St Mary's Church is 15th century, but the majority of the building is later. The church has one of the largest buttressed spires in Cambridgeshire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.druidic.org/camchurch/churches/whittleseymary.htm |title=Whittlesey, St Mary |work=Cambridgeshire Churches website |publisher=Druidic.org |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> It also contains a chapel which was restored in 1862 as a memorial to [[Sir Harry Smith]].<ref>http://www.genuki.org.uk/big/eng/CAM/WhittleseyStMary/</ref>
St Andrew's Church is a mixture of the Perpendicular and Decorated styles of Gothic, and has records back to 1635.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.druidic.org/camchurch/churches/whittleseyandrew.htm |title=Whittlesey, St Andrew's |work=Cambridgeshire Churches website |publisher=Druidic.org |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref>
===The Market Place=== The Market Place is the site of the town's market, held every Friday. A right to hold a weekly market was first granted in 1715, although there have been several periods since then during which the market did not function, for example from the late 1700s until about 1850.<ref name="North Witchford Hundred">{{cite web |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=21904&strquery=whittlesey |title=North Witchford Hundred - Whittlesey |work=A History of the County of Cambridge and the Isle of Ely: Volume 4: City of Ely; Ely, N. and S. Witchford and Wisbech Hundreds |year=2002 |pages= |editor=R B Pugh |publisher=British History Online (online version)}}</ref><ref name="North Witchford Hundred" />
In the centre of the Market Place is the [[Buttercross]], dating back to 1680. Originally a place for people to sell goods at market, the structure was considered useless in the 1800s and was only saved from demolition when a local businessman donated some slate tiles for the roof. It served as a bus shelter, until the controversial relocation of bus services from the Market Place to a purpose-built terminal in Grosvenor Road.<ref>Bus terminal [http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/politics/politics-news/re-location-for-whittlesey-bus-stop-as-new-500-000-scheme-begins-1-6548243].</ref>
==Whittlesey today== [[File:Looking north from St. Mary's church, Whittlesey.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Looking north over the Market Place from the spire of St Mary's during the 2012 Whittlesey Festival]] [[File:The George Hotel, Whittlesey.jpg|thumb|250px|left|The 18th-century George Hotel (now a [[Wetherspoons]] pub) decorated for the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Queen's Diamond Jubilee]] in June 2012]] The Whittlesey Summer Festival, held annually in September, takes over much of the town centre. Attractions in recent years have included a large classic car display, a large Italian food stall, fairground rides, a [[steam engine]], and in 2009, a flying display by a [[Hawker Hurricane]] of the [[Battle of Britain Memorial Flight]].<ref>{{cite web |date=16 September 2009 |url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/whittleseynews/Families-flock-to-Whittlesey-Summer.5653548.jp |work=[[Peterborough Evening Telegraph|Peterborough Today]] |title=Families flock to Whittlesey Summer Festival |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> An art competition, for students of [[Sir Harry Smith Community College]] also runs with the festival, with entries displayed throughout the day in the Whittlesey Christian Church. The festival in 2009 also saw the people of Whittlesey raise £10,000 for [[bushfire]] victims in [[Whittlesea, Victoria|Whittlesea]], Melbourne.<ref>{{cite web |date=20 May 2009 |url=http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/Derek-Stebbing-is-new-Mayor.5286677.jp |work=[[Peterborough Evening Telegraph|Peterborough Today]] |title=Derek Stebbing is new Mayor of Whittlesey |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref>
From 2011 to 2015 the town was the location of a long-running planning battle between rival supermarket chains [[Tesco]] and [[Sainsbury's]], which competed to build on neighbouring sites in Eastrea Road. Dubbed "Supermarket Gate" by the local press, the dispute was eventually resolved when Sainsbury's won approval for its supermarket, business park and country park development in June 2015.<ref>[http://www.wisbechstandard.co.uk/news/perseverance_pays_off_as_sainsbury_s_get_committee_s_approval_for_a_supermarket_and_country_park_in_whittlesey_1_4122314]</ref> Plans for over 400 houses on an adjacent site, construction of which began in late 2014,<ref>New housing [https://easternnewhomebuyer.wordpress.com/2014/11/18/larkfleet-starts-work-on-new-whittlesey-development/]</ref> also generated some controversy when approved,<ref>Plans approved [http://www.peterboroughtoday.co.uk/news/community/community-news/whittlesey-460-new-homes-plan-gets-go-ahead-1-2581277]</ref> due to concerns about the additional traffic generated on the [[A605]].
Located close to the King's Dyke brickworks are three 80-metre [[wind turbine]]s, the largest on-shore turbines in England, which power the [[McCain Foods Limited|McCains chips]] plant.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mccain.co.uk/info/press-releases/wind-turbines.aspx |title=McCain introduces winds of change to UK's largest chip factory |format=press-release |publisher=Mccain.co.uk |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref>
The town has one secondary school, [[Sir Harry Smith Community College]], which opened in 1953 on the site of [[Whittlesey Workhouse]],<ref>{{cite web |first=Peter |last=Higginbotham |url=http://www.workhouses.org.uk/Whittlesey/ |title=The Workhouse in Whittlesey, Cambridge |publisher=www.workhouses.org.uk |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref> and three primary schools. There is another primary school in the neighbouring village of [[Coates, Cambridgeshire|Coates]].
[[Whittlesey Museum]], in the Old Town Hall, has collections to do with the natural and cultural heritage of Whittlesey and the surrounding area.<ref>Opening hours, etc. [http://www.cambridgeshire.net/organisation/whittlesey-museum/8824.aspx Retrieved 21 February 2014.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224125720/http://www.cambridgeshire.net/organisation/whittlesey-museum/8824.aspx |date=24 February 2014}}</ref>
==Whittlesea Straw Bear== [[File:Straw Bear.jpg|thumb|200px|The Whittlesea Straw Bear 2008]] [[File:PigDykeMollyMusicians.jpg|thumb|200px|Musicians of Pig Dyke Molly dance team playing at Whittlesea Straw Bear Festival 2007]] The festival of the Straw Bear or "Strawbower" is an old custom known only from a small area of Fenland on the borders of [[Huntingdonshire]] and [[Cambridgeshire]], including [[Ramsey Mereside]].<ref>{{Cite book |last=Hole |first=Christina |title=A Dictionary of British Folk Customs |page=286 |publisher=Paladin |year=1978 |isbn=0-586-08293-X}}</ref> (Similar ritual animals have been known in other parts of Europe, and still appear in parts of Germany at [[Shrove Tuesday|Shrovetide]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fideler-aff.de/web-content/brauchtumsfiguren.html |title=FG "Fideler Aff" e.V. Walldürn |publisher=Fideler-aff.de |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wallduern.de/ceasy/modules/cms/main.php5?cPageId=331 |title=Stadt Walldürn - Kraft schöpfen im Odenwald | Ahoi und Helau - Faschenaacht bei den Affen, Dundern und Höhgöikern |publisher=Wallduern.de |date=2 January 2006 |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=16_-_05.02.08 |url=http://www.helau-ocv.de/bilder/2008/05.02.08%20strohbaer/slides/16_-_05.02.08.html |title=16_-_05.02.08 | ja album |Image 7 of 20 |publisher=Helau-ocv.de |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219141105/http://www.helau-ocv.de/bilder/2008/05.02.08%20strohbaer/slides/16_-_05.02.08.html |archivedate=19 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last=Fraser |first=Sir James George |title=The Golden Bough, A Study in Magic and Religion (Abridged Edition) |page=306 |publisher=Macmillan |year=1963 |isbn=}}</ref>)
On Plough Tuesday, the day after the first Monday after [[Twelfth Night]], a man or a boy would be covered from head to foot in straw and led from house to house where he would dance in exchange for gifts of money, food or beer. The festival was of a stature that farmers would often reserve their best straw for the making of the bear.<ref name="strawbearsite">[http://www.strawbear.org.uk/History.htm Straw Bear Festival website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515005958/http://www.strawbear.org.uk/History.htm|date=15 May 2009}} <!--accessed 2008-11-14--></ref>
The custom died out in about 1909, probably because the local police regarded it as begging, but it was resurrected by the Whittlesea Society in 1980.<ref name=strawbearsite/>
The festival has now expanded to cover the whole weekend when the Bear appears (not Plough Tuesday nowadays, but the second weekend in January instead). On the Saturday of the festival, the Bear processes around the streets with its attendant "keeper" and musicians, followed by numerous traditional dance sides (mostly visitors), including [[Morris dance|morris men and women]], [[molly dance]]rs, [[Rapper sword|rapper]] and [[Long Sword dance|longsword dancers]], [[Clogging|clog dancers]] and others, who perform at various points along the route.<ref name=strawbearsite/>
The Bear dances to a tune (reminiscent of the hymn "[[Jesus Bids us Shine]]") which featured on ''Rattlebone and Ploughjack'', a 1976 [[LP album|LP]] by [[Ashley Hutchings]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.strawbear.org.uk/Saturday%20Procession.htm |title=Straw Bear Festival website – Procession |publisher=Strawbear.org.uk |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226065427/http://www.strawbear.org.uk/Saturday%20Procession.htm |archivedate=26 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> along with a spoken description of the original custom (which partly inspired the Whittlesey revival).
[[Pub session|"Sessions"]] of traditional music take place in many of the [[public house]]s during the day and evening, and a [[barn dance]] or [[Céilidh|ceilidh]] and a [[Cajun]] dance round off the Saturday night.<ref>[http://www.strawbear.org.uk/Festival%202009.htm Straw Bear Festival website – Festival 2009] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828112416/http://www.strawbear.org.uk/Festival%202009.htm |date=28 August 2008 }}</ref> The bear "costume" is burned at a ceremony on Sunday lunchtime,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.strawbear.org.uk/Sunday%20Burning.htm |title=Straw Bear Festival website – Burning |publisher=Strawbear.org.uk |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226065437/http://www.strawbear.org.uk/Sunday%20Burning.htm |archivedate=26 December 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> (just as, in Germany, the Shrovetide bear costumes are also ceremonially burned after use).<ref>{{cite web |author=30_-_20.02.07 |url=http://www.helau-ocv.de/bilder/2007/20.02.07%20strohbaer/slides/30_-_20.02.07.html |title=30_-_20.02.07 | ja album |Image 21 of 27 |publisher=Helau-ocv.de |date= |accessdate=6 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219141152/http://www.helau-ocv.de/bilder/2007/20.02.07%20strohbaer/slides/30_-_20.02.07.html |archivedate=19 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Whittlesea Straw Bear and Keeper are featured on the album art of [[The Young Knives]]' album, ''[[Voices of Animals and Men]]''.
==Famous residents== ===Sir Harry Smith=== [[Harry Smith (army)|Sir Harry George Waklyn Smith]] (1788–1860), best known for his role in the [[Battle of Aliwal]] (India), was born in Whittlesey. His military career saw him rise from a rifleman to a major general and Baronet of Aliwal. He was governor of the [[Cape of Good Hope]] from 1847 to 1852, during a period of intense unrest. Smith featured in ''Rifles'' by [[Mark Urban]], about the [[95th Rifles]] Napoleonic campaigns through Spain to Waterloo, during which time he was a junior officer and served with his two brothers.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} He is commemorated through the Whittlesey area, giving his name to the [[Sir Harry Smith Community College]] and community centre, for example. There is a bust of him in St Mary's Church. There is a pub named ''The Hero of Aliwal'' and a street named Aliwal Road in his honour. The house where he was born bears a plaque with his name. At the time of his death, the building was used as a school, but at present it is a private house.<ref>{{IoE |403375 |accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> He is buried in the local cemetery.
===L. P. Hartley=== Another famous son of Whittlesey is the renowned author [[L. P. Hartley]].
===David Proud=== Actor [[David Proud]], who was the first disabled actor to have a regular role in ''[[EastEnders]]'', lived in Whittlesey and attended [[Sir Harry Smith Community College]]. The Supportive Skills department at the school is named The David Proud Suite in his honour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidproud.co.uk/component/content/article/1-press/10-the-qdavid-proud-suiteq-at-sir-harry-smiths-college |title=The "David Proud Suite" at Sir Harry's |publisher=Davidproud.co.uk |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=6 September 2010}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Must Farm Bronze Age settlement]] *[[John Clare]]'s poem "The Shepherds Calendar", mentions Whittlesea in the verse for January. *[[List of places in Cambridgeshire]] *[[Straw bear]] (German traditional character) *[[Sir Harry Smith Community College]] *[[Whittlesey Workhouse]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.text:
[[Image:ClubDeiBrutti.jpg|right]] The '''World Association of Ugly People''' (in [[Italian language|Italian]] '''Club dei Brutti''') is an organization dedicated to fighting for the recognition of [[Ugliness|ugly]] people, in a society that places a high value on physical beauty. The group's motto is "A person is what he is and not what he looks like".
== History == The club claims to have a history in [[Piobbico]], [[Italy]], from 1879. It was launched again in 1963 as a marriage agency for the town's single women.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/3107852.stm|date=14 September 2003|title=Italy's ugly club defies convention|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2007-09-10}}</ref>
The World Association of Ugly People club campaigns against [[Inclusion (disability rights)|discrimination]] in the workplace based on looks. It attempts to make society more aware of ugly people's problems. It also helps people overcome their phobias and, in some cases, to find partners.<ref name="BBC"/>
In 2007, the group unveiled a monument dedicated to ugly people in Piobbico's town square. The monument depicts an unknown person looking at his reflection in a mirror.<ref name="Ananova">{{cite news|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617175648/http://www.ananova.com/news/story/sm_2496659.html|archive-date=17 June 2008|url=http://www.ananova.com/news/story/sm_2496659.html|date=9 September 2007|title=Monument to the ugly|publisher=Ananova|accessdate=2007-09-10}}</ref>
== Traditions == The club's emblem is the head of a wild boar. The club's crest features a reclining man smoking a pipe with the slogan: "Ugliness is a virtue, beauty is slavery".<ref name="BBC"/>
The club's patron is [[Vulcan (mythology)|Vulcan]] from [[Roman mythology]]. At birth Vulcan was so ugly that his mother threw him over a cliff. He survived and became a skilled blacksmith. For providing [[Achilles]] with superior weapons, he was admitted to [[Mount Olympus]] where he married the beautiful [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]], goddess of love.<ref>[http://www.igs.net/~tonyc/inugly.html Support for the Ugly]</ref>
=== President === The members of the World Association of Ugly People elect their president annually during the ''Festival of the Ugly''. This event is hosted by the small town of Piobbico in the [[Marche]] region of Italy every year on the first Sunday of September.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/news/pictures/slideshow?collectionId=1009 |date=9 September 2007|title=Festival of the Ugly|publisher=Reuter|accessdate=2007-09-10}}</ref>
Every year until 2007, Telesforo Iacobelli won the top prize and was president of the club, owing to his dedication to the organization. Also, he has a small nose in a culture where large noses are considered beautiful.<ref name="BBC"/> On August 21, 2006, Iacobelli died.<ref>[http://www.wuz.it/news/10786/morto-presidente-club.html Dead president of the club ugly] (in Italian). August 22, 2006.</ref>
== Members == The following people have been members of the association.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071217165429/http://www.clubdeibrutti.com/storia.html Club dei Brutti- About Us] on Internet Archive</ref>
* [[Giulio Andreotti]] * [[Maurizio Costanzo]] * [[Mike Bongiorno]] * [[Paolo Bonolis]] * [[Pippo Franco]] * [[Piero Badaloni]] * [[Alessandro Cecchi Paone]] * [[Gerry Scotti]] * [[Maria Amelia Monti]] * [[Cinzia De Ponti]]
== In popular culture == In 2010, the Association provided inspiration for the song "Club Dei Brutti" by the English band Idiot Savant.<ref>[http://vimeo.com/12645557/ Idiot Savant - Club Dei Brutti] Club Dei Brutti by Idiot Savant</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://wandererseye.com/pictures/main.php?g2_itemId=263 Picture of the door to the Club dei Brutti]
